JOHN COLLINS . I am a hatter, and live in Guildford—street. On the 22nd of Aug. the prisoner came to our house, about eleven o'clock in the morning—he was very drunk, and came to inquire if there was not a lady who had lost a parcel—we told him to go next door—he then said he knew about the property—he knew where there was a gown pawned in Suffolk—street, and that he saw the ticket burnt—Mrs. Hutton then came and said it was her handkerchief that he had on—he took it off and gave it her.
MRS. HUTTON. I gave him 6d. for porterage.

Prisoner's Defence, This lady had the bundles in the Southwark Bridge—road, she asked me where there was a public—house open; we went on, and she said the things were very loose, and all over mud; she gave roe this handkerchief to tie my hand up; she asked me to carry these things to the Monument public—house; it was not open; she went into the coffee—housp, and left them there; she then went to Guildford—street, went up stairs, and called out of window to tell me to stop; I waited nearly half—an—hour, and she did not give me anything; she was very much in liquor; I have never been to the coffee—house since.

GUILTY . Aged 52.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1959.
WILLIAM THOMPSON was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
NOT GUILTY .

1960.
JOSEPH PHILLIPS was indicted
for stealing 15 yards of ribbon, value 7s., the goods of
William Quelch.

GEORGE DOUGLASS . I am assistant to William Quelch, who lives in South—wark. The prisoner was in the habit of coming to his shop to sell artificial—flowers—he came there on the 27th of Aug.—I was serving a lady with some ribbons—I pushed the box on one side; but previous to doing so, I counted the ribbons—there were twenty pieces of them—the customer left the shop—the prisoner came and offered to sell me flowers—I said we did not want any—he put his box on a chair in the shop, and the box lid partly over the box of ribbons on the counter—I said we did not want any—I went into the midd
le opf the shope and then towards the parlour—in three minutes after I came I to the shop again—he had then left—I counted the ribbons, and found there was one piece gone—I am sure no one else had been in the shop—I went after him—I overtook him, and said I wanted him—he came back—I told him—I overtook him, and said I wanted him—he came back—I told him to open his box, Which he did, and I found this ribbon in the box—it is William Quelch's—I said, "I have found you out at last, having missed goods before, I suspected you"—he said it fell into his box—from the situation in which the ribbon was, it is impossible it could fall into his box without his knowledge—it had been in a box, and could not roll out without being pulled out.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What is the value of this rib
bon? A. 7s.—there were three or four small bunches of flowers on the counter.

GUILTY . Aged 77.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury,—
Confined Four Months.

1961.
WILLIAM STANDEN was indicted
for stealing 1 live crab, price 1s., the property of the
South Eastern Railway Company.
MR. HUDDLESTON conducted the Prosecution,

WILLIAM SHAW . I am a clerk to the South Eastern Railway Company—the prisoner was their porter at the Bricklayer's Arms station—it was his duty to unlock the trucks of fish in the morning, which come up from Dover and Ashford by the night trains, and to put them in different places for the carriers to take away—on Monday morning, the 14th of Sept., I saw him on the stage between three and four o'clock—he walked to the top of the stage—I perceived something under his arm—I watched him—he left the ware—house, and got into the road—I followed, and asked what he had got—he said, "A few apples"—I put my hand under his jacket and pulled out a live crab—there were such articles came up that morning—I asked where he got it from—he said, "From a basket in the warehouse"—that is a warehouse belonging to the Company—he said, "Let me put it back again"—I said, "No, I cannot countenance a thing of that sort, I shall be compelled to give you into custody"—I allowed him to go into the warehouse—I found a po
liceman, and gave him into custody—I went into the warehouse—there were baskets of live crabs there—they were all tied down—I should think this was not a crab that could have got out of itself.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. You would not swear it could not have got out? A. I should say not—it was not very large nor small—I never saw a crab in the warehouse before—the prisoner did not say he picked it up—he said he took it out of the basket—he had been twelve months in the Company's employ, and had a good character.
COURT. Q. If crabs did get out, would it be your duty, or the duty of the servants to put them back A. Yes.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 20.——
Confined Six Months.

1962.
ROBERT BISHOP was indicted
for feloniously receiving 2 bushels and 3 gallons of oats and beans mixed, value 6s.; I bushel and 3 pecks of oats, 4s.; and 2 pecks of beans, 1s. 6d.; the goods of
William Moon; well knowing them to have been stolen. (See page 833, No.1979)

WILLIAM MOON . I carry on the business of a carrier at Godalming, in Surrey, and am a farmer. I had a person named Edwards in my employ as a carter—on Thursday, the 10th of Sept., it was his duty, with Wiggins, to take the cart to town—on Sunday, the 6th of Sept, I saw a sack containing corn in my hay—loft, which excited my suspicion—my stable is at the bottom, and is about fifty feet long, and at the top of that is my corn—loft and hay
loft—you go through the hay—loft to get to the corn—loft—for the last two or three months I have given out all the corn myself—the corn has been pad
locked up—the padlock has been on perhaps for twelve months—on the Monday and Thursday, Edwards, the carter, had four horses up, and he had two sacks of corn and one of chaff—the sack which I found on Sunday in the hay—loft was covered with a little bay—the constable saw it—he has had access to my stable for the last month—on the Thursday morning I saw there were two lots of corn, one in the corner of the stable, and one in the hay—loft—the sack was lying in the same situation as on Sunday—I did not mix anything with the corn in the sack—I have seen the corn that Bid—decombe found in London on the Friday—I believe, to the best of my knowledge, it is my corn—mine consisted of white oats, black oats, and split beans, and this consisted of the same—something had been mixed with it, but I did not do that—apart from that I believe it to be my corn.

Cross-examined by MR. LOCKE. Q. Do you mean you had not mixed any
thing with it? A. Not with that in the sack—I did with that in the corn loft—I mixed some chickens' grits with that—that was about four or five bushels—I had perhaps ten quarters in the bulk—what I mixed was not in any sack at all, it was in a heap—I gave out the corn on Thursday morning which Edwards was to take with his horses—I went into the granary to get the corn, and Edwards went with me—I filled the bushels, and tipped them into his sack—that was not the marked sack, it was a sack the constable found in the wagon, with a portion of corn in it.

WILLIAM WIGGINS . I am in the service of Mr. Moon. It was my duty to go with the wagon on this occasion to London—on Thursday, the 10th, there were three sacks that had corn in them put into the wagon, and one that had chaff—Edwards ought to have had two with corn and one with chaff—I went with the wagon to the Queen's Head, in London—it was not my duty to put the sacks in, or to take them out—I have to look to the goods, and have nothing to do with the horses—when we came to the Queen's Head I had to unload the wagon—it was Edward's place to take out the sacks and the chaff—I did not do it, it must have been done by him—my master has a stable at the Queen's Head, in the Borough, and the prisoner has a stable about ten yards from my master's—I did not see Edwards and the prisoner together on the Thursday or the Friday—the prisoner is a carrier—he has a horse—I be
lieve he carries to some place in Kent.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner was out carrying on that occasion? A. I do not know—I never saw him at all on the day we arrived—I believe he only has a part of that stable—all sorts of horses are put there that come to the Queen's Head—the ostler has the care of it—I do not know where the ostler is—I was at the Queen's Head this morning—he was not there—I do not know when I last saw him there—I did not see him there the day that I and Edwards went with that load—I do not know whether there was any ostler there—the ostler goes by the name of Charles East—I do not know where he is—I missed him last week.
MR. CHARNOCK. Q. How many stables are there in this yard? A. Fow or five—I do not know of the prisoner having other horses there—as far as I know he has the stable to himself.
COURT. Q. You told us he only occupied part of the stable? A. No more he does—other people put their horses there—the ostler, Charles East, has the care of the stable.

WILLIAM BIDDKCOMBE . I am constable of the borough of Godalming—"consequence of information from Mr. Moon, I mixed about a quart of grits with a sack of corn, which I found in his hay—loft—I marked the sack with a piece of grey worsted, and a piece of red string—it was covered with hay and straw—you had to pass very near to it to go to the corn—loft—on the Thurs
day following, I went into the same stable, at two o'clock in the morning, and found about two bushels of white oats, black oats, and split beans concealed, and with that I mixed a quantity of chickens' grits, and a few peas—I then took a sample of the mixture, which I have here—on Friday morning I then fol
lowed the wagon to the Queen's Head in the Borough—it arrived about half past five that morning—I did not see it unloaded—I was so well knows "that yard it would not do for me to go in—I put another constable there—I went that day to Mr. Moon's stable—I could not find the sack nor any corn—I went to a stable ten or twenty yards off—the prisoner came in while I was there—I pointed to a horse there, and asked him if it was his—he said, "yes"—under the manger I saw three sacks; one contained chaff, another peas and pollard, and between them was three sacks; one contained chaff, another peas and pollard, and between them was a sack containing about two bushels of mixed oats—I asked if those three parcels belonged to him—he said they did—I took the sack containing the oats, and brought

it to the door—he was close by my side—I took some of the oats out—I asked where he got those oats—he said, "I bought them"—I said, "Where?"—he said, "Over here"—I said, "Where do you mean by over here?"—he said, "At the corn—chandler's, at the corner of Tooley—street"—I was in plain clothes, but I told him I was a police—constable—he then said, "Well, the fact is, I know nothing about them; it is not mine at all"—I swear to these being a part of the lot I marked—the sack they were in was not the sack I had marked—that sack was brought to me—Goff took it out of the wagon at Nine Elms.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know anything about this stable? A. I do not—the prisoner said it was his horse, and these three parcels belonged to him—I had not then shown him the contents of any of them.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant L 8.) On Friday, the 11th of Sept., I watched, and met Edwards, the carman, driving a wagon in Ken
nington—lane—I followed it to Nine Elms, and found two sacks in it—I took one sack out, and showed it to Biddecombe—I took Edwards into custody—I found some keys on him—he gave me some account of them—I applied two large key to his street—door; it did not fit it—I applied two of the keys to the corn—loft, and they fitted.

1963.
ANN LEWIS,
ANN WALES , and
THOMAS FREEBODY , were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s. the goods of
John Clark, from his person.

JOHN CLARK . I live in Westmorland—row, Southwark. On the 25th of Aug., at half—past eleven o'clock at night, I was in the Old Kent—road, turning np the corner of King—street—Lewis met me, and asked me to give her something to drink—it being late I was rather alarmed—I put my hand to my pocket to give her 1 1/2 d. to get a glass of beer, which she asked for; and in the mean time, she put her hand into my pocket, and drew my hand
kerchief out—I seized her by her clothes, and held her—she threw it to Wales, who was standing in a dark corner—I am sure it was her—I kept hold of Lewis, intending to give her into custody—when I came to the end of East—lane, Freebody came up to me, and said, "Let go the woman"—that was about three—hundred yards from where I lost my handkerchief—Free—body struck me under the ear, and knocked me down—the policeman came up, and I gave him in charge—Lewis got from me when I fell—I had such a tremendous blow on the side of my head that the blood gushed out of my ear.
Lewis. Q. Did I take your handkerchief? A. Yes—I felt your hand in my pocket—I tore your clothes in holding you.
Wales. Q. Can you swear you saw me up the dark turning? A. Yes, at the corner of it—I saw you pick the handkerchief up.

JOHN MENHINICK (police-constable M 20.) I heard a noise at a quarter before twelve o'clock, and saw a mob of people at the corner of East—lane—I went up, and found the prosecutor surrounded by a great number of persons—he said he had been robbed by two females, and he held one some time, till Freebody came, knocked him down, and rescued the female from him—I gave Freebody to an officer—I went and took Lewis and Wales, from the description the prosecutor gave—I brought them back, and he iden
tified them—I know Lewis and Freebody are acquainted—I have seen hem together frequently.
lewis. Q. When did you see me with him? A. For the last four or five years, except the time when one or the other of you were in prison.
THOMAS WEBB (police-constable M 174.) I took Freebody—I found this tippet in his pocket, which Lewis claimed as hers.

Lewis's Defence. I was standing at the corner of King—street; Mr. Clark crossed the road, and asked me to walk down with him; when I got down he gave me 1 1/2 d., and because I would not submit to him, he tore my clothes, and then said, "You stole my handkerchief;" I said, "If I have, call a policeman;" he would not, but wanted to pull me down Surrey—square; he would not, submit to him, he tore my clothes and then said, "You stole my handkerchief;" I said, "if I have, calls policeman;" he would not, but wanted to pull me down surrey—square; he said if I did not go down a turning with him, he would cut me with a razor; several men came up; he dropped his umbrella; he took it up and struck me and I struck him again; Freebody did not strike him; the officer came up, and I told him what was the matter; the prosecutor had torn my frock; I wanded to pin it up; I went to the Railway and met Wales; she was giving me a pin, and the officer came and took us.
Wales's Defence. I had not seen Lewis for three weeks; I met her by accident, and she asked me for a pin.

JURY to JOHN CLARK. Q. Were you sober? A. Yes—I only had 4d. worth of gin and water at the Green Man—I have not the least doubt of the prisoners—I have seen Lewis and Freebody about the road—I did not see Wales when Lewis came up—I was going home.
COURT. Q. What are you? A. I was in the police—I left it about twelve years ago—I have a stipend from Government.

LEWIS—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Nine Months.

WALES—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

FREEBODY †—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1964.
JOHN COFFIN was indicted
for stealing 1 10l. Bank note, and 6 5l. notes, the property of
Alfred Davis.

ALFRED DAVIS . I am a law stationer, and live in Castle—street, Holborn. On the 21st of Aug. I played "Richard the Third", in a private theatrical performance, at the Bower Saloon in Stangate—street—I believe it is a licensed theatre—when I went to play I took one 10l. note, and six 5l. notes, which were in my pocket, and transferred them from my own clothes to my theatrical pantaloons, which I had on—the prisoner acted as prompter—I lost my property that night—I took off the pantaloons about ten o'clock that night, and threw them from the dressing—room, in which I had been dressed, into another dressing—room, and my impression is that I omitted taking the money out of the pantaloons—one of the notes has been traced—the prisoner was with me part of the time when I undressed—I do not know what became of him when I threw the pantaloons over—if I see the notes I can identify them—here is one with the name of "Butcher and Son" on it, in my writing—here is another with the same writing on it—these are two of the 5l. notes, and this is the 10l. note, which is also mine.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. What is the writing? A. This, in front of the notes—it signifies the person from whom I received them—I am in the habit of receiving notes from Mr. Butcher—a note received from him at some other time would have the same mark—there were 500 or 600 persons at the theatre—I cannot say whether the audience part is between the stage and the saloon—there is a public—house there—I have known the prisoner many years—he has borne a most irreproachable character, and he has been on in
timate terms with me—this money was done up in a way that he could not possibly know I had it—I cannot say that I did not drop it—I had it in the pantaloons of Richard the Third—I cannot say it did not fall out—it was in a kind of breeches pocket—I cannot say that the prisoner might not have left the place before I did—I do not recollect seeing him after the performance

was over, though I understand he was there till three o'clock in the morning—he was decidedly intoxicated that night—I heard he called the next morning at my place, and wished particularly to see me, but I was not up—I did not get to bed till five o'clock, though I was at home—I believe the prisoner is a law—stationer—I never heard an imputation on his character—my impression is that he did not intend to appropriate the notes—I have seen him in a state of drunkenness before, and when he is so he does not know what he is about.

ROBERT THOMAS BARNES . I am superintendent of the police. I took the prisoner in Hertfordshire—I told him what I took him for—he said he did not know such a person as Mr. Davis, I was mistaken in the person—he repeated that two or three times—I asked his name, and he refused to give it—I said, from the description in the Gazette, I believed him to be the man—I searched him, and found this 5l. note and a Post—office order on him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you say one single syllable to him about Mr. Davis before you apprehended him A. I did—I told him I took him for taking these notes from Mr. Davis—he said he did not know him, I was mistaken in the person—I believe I said that before the Magistrate—I have every reason to believe so—what I said was read over to me—I see it is not mentioned in this deposition.

CHARLES GOOD . I was with Mr. Barnes—I searched the prisoner after he had searched him—I found this 10l. note in his fob—Mr. Barnes told him he apprehended him on suspicion, a description having appeared in the "Police Gazette"—he said he was mistaken in the person—we read the "Gazette" to him—it states it was the property of Mr. Davis—we had seen the prisoner on the Monday before we took him—he was spending money very lavishly—we watched the "Gazette" every day, and waited till this appeared in the "Gazette."

Cross-examined. Q. Did not he say he knew Mr. Davis? A. He did afterwards—he was sober on the Monday night, and on the Thursday night when we took him—I did not see him between those times—he said he would come before the proper authorities, and account for the notes.
MICHAEL COCKLING . I am a shoemaker, and live in Baldwin's—gardens—the prisoner bought a pair of boots of my father—he brought a 5l. note—Mr. Low changed it for him.

WILLIAM LOW . I changed a 5l. note for Mr. Cockling—I believe the pri
soner is the man who was with him—this is the note.
CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant 8l.)I took this 5l. note from the Bank of England to Mr. Low, and he identified it as the one he changed.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 34.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.—
Confined Four Months.

1965.
NICHOLAS LOGAN was indicted
for stealing 1 looking—glass, value 10s., the goods of
Charles Connaughton: also 1 gown, 2l., and 1 scarf, 1l., the goods of
Alexander Montgomery; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1966.
JOHN WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing 19 lbs. weight of ham, value 13s., the goods of
George Poulton; and that he had been before con
victed of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Nine Months.

1967.
JAMES BUTTON was indicted
for stealing 1 waistcoat, value 14s., the goods of
William Churchyard.

WILLIAM CHURCHYARD . I am a tailor, and live at Clapham. About eleven or twelve o'clock, on the 17th of Sept., I left my shop, and when I re
turned I missed a waistcoat—I went out and met the prisoner—I asked if he had been at Clapham that morning—he said, "Yes"—I asked him what he had got in his pocket—he said, "A rule"—I found this black waistcoat in his pocket—it is mine.

COURT. Q. When you came home, did you see anybody leave your shop? A. Yes—I found the prisoner with the waistcoat, in about an hour afterward, and he was dressed as the person was who left the shop—I said to him, "What have you got?"—he said he had nothing but a rule, and afterwards he said he had the waistcoat.

Prisoner's Defence. The gentleman said he thought it was me. I bought it of a young man with a fustian coat; I do not know him; he came and asked me if I wanted to buy a waistcoat; I gave him 6s. for it; when this gentleman came, he asked me if I had got a waistcoat? I said, "Yes, a double—breasted waistcoat."

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1968.
JOHN BEAZELEY was indicted
for unlawfully assaulting
Louisa Powell, with intent, &c.; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .
Confined Nine Months.

1969.
CHARLES SMITH was indicted
for stealing 1 blanket, value 3s. and 1 counterpane, 1s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Eley.

THOMAS ELEY . I am a tailor, and live in Granby—street, Waterloo—road—in the middle of Aug. the prisoner came tomy house to live with a woman, and agreed to pay me the rent by instalments, half on Wednesday and half on Saturday, which they did the first week—the second week went on till the Thursday—I named it, and he said, "You shall have it by—and—bye"—it went on till the Saturday, the middle of the day—I asked him, and he said, "You need not keep asking about your rent; if you do, I shall pay you and go"—I said, I do not care if you do"—I went into their room on the Sunday—I found they were both out, and missed a blanket—while I was there the prisoner came and said, "Did you think I was gone?"—I said, "Itlooked very much like it; you have shut the place up, and gone out"—he said, "You are not a fool"—I said, "No, not quite; but where is the blanket?"—he said, "I do not know"—I said, "Well, I shall keep you here till the policeman comes"—he went to the tea—caddy and gave me the duplicate of the blanket—he said, "Here is the ticket; will you forgive me, if I give you one shilling"—(it was pawned for one shilling)—I said, "No"—I took the shilling—he said, "You" are not going to turn me out"—I said, "No, but you must go down in the kitchen, and I lock this room up"—on the Monday my wife came home, and said, "They have got the counterpane."
Prisoner. She keeps a house of ill—fame. Witness. It is a lodging—house.
COURT. Q. Is it not a house where men and women come to sleep? A. one lodger has been in the house six years and another seven.
Prisoner. He has three females, two walk the Strand every night, iw another walks Pall—mall; the woman I was with used to go out, and brought in several men, and I went out. Witness. That is false.
ELIZABETH ELEY . I missed a counterpane—the duplicate of it has not been found—the counterpane was lost while they occupied my woman took the apartment, but the prisoner lived with her.
Prisoner. Q. Did you have any gin with the young woman that was there? A. I did
COURT. Q. Was she a prostitute? A. Yes.
NOT GUILTY .

1970.
CHARLES SMITH was again indicted
for stealing 1 blanket, value 2s.; and 1 counterpane, 1s. 6d. the goods of
George Freeman.

SARAH FREEMAN . I am the wife of George Freeman—he is a lighterman.—the prisoner came to lodge with us with a woman, on Monday, August 31st—on the following Sunday evening he came and said that on Monday he would pay the rent—my husband said, "Very well"—on the Monday morning he came down, opened the bed—room, and said, "Can I make a fire?"—my husband said "Yes"—he said, "I have not got a bit of wood, can you lend me a halfpenny?"—he got the wood, made a fire, then he find the woman went out with a bundle—I went up stairs, and the blanket and counterpane were gone—I went out, and while I was gone a note came with the duplicate in it, and on the note was written "The money shall be paid on Thursday."
Prisoner. Q. Did I take the room? A. The woman came first, you came in about ten minutes after—I have no girls in the back room.

Prisoner, I was at this woman's one or two nights; I went out on the Monday morning at half—past eight; I told the woman I watt with that I was quite tired, and would go home; I went, and was at home with my parents; I had left it altogether; I never knew these things were pledged,

THOMAS CROSBIE (police-constable Z 189.) I had this duplicate given me—it is dated 7th September, for one blanket and counterpane, 3s. 6d. pawned by a female, in the name of A. Price—these are the articles.
Prisoner. Mrs. Freeman said if I could find the girl she would not hurt a hair of my head, as she knew I was innocent.

SARAH FREEMAN
re-examined. No—I did not.

CODRT. Q. How old was the girl? A. She might be twenty—two or
twenty—three—he told me I should find her in the workhouse—I went all the way up to Hyde—park to find her and could not—the prisoner and her quitted together.
NOT GUILTY .

1971.
GEORGE PATTISON was indicted
for stealing 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 1 jacket,35s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 25s.; and 1 handkerchief, 6d., the property of
John Towers.

JOHN TOWERS . I am a seaman, and lodge at Mrs. Spurrier's, College—street, Horsley—down—the prisoner came to lodge there last Friday afternoon—I had my chest in the kitchen—it was not locked—I had a jacket, waistcoat, and trowsers in it—I left them in the chest and the prisoner in the house on Friday—I returned home about twelve o'clock—I found I had left my chest unlocked and my clothes were gone—these are my clothes.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not go with me to fetch my clothes up A. Yes, we were drinking—I did not leave the key in my chest and say you was welcome to anything—you asked if I had any tobacco—I went to my chest and you had an opportunity of seeing what was in it.

ELIZABETH SPURRIER . The prisoner and prosecutor lodged with me—the prosecutor came home and told me of his loss—I went after the prisoner and overtook him—he had these clothes on—I said, "How could you do such a thing, you have got John's clothes on"—he ran away—I called, "Stop thief," ami he was stopped several streets off.
THOMAS SUMMERSLY (police-constable M 202.) I took the prisoner—he was not drunk—he resisted me.
Prisoner. He said he would let me have anything he had till I got my wages; all my sea—clothes were in the house.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Six Months.

1972.
JESSE GOODRICH was indicted
for stealing 1 table—cloth, value 1s., the goods of the
Guardians of the Poor of the Wandsworth and Clapham Union; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1973.
MARGARET FORD was indicted
for stealing 1 umbrella, value 2s., the goods of
John Rayner; and that she had been twice before convicted of felony.

ANN CAROLINE BROWN . I am servant to Mr. John Rayner, of Landsdown—villas, Clapham—road. On the 22nd of Aug., about two o'clock, the prisoner and another girl came in at our door and concealed themselves ia the house—the gardener told us they were in the house—they went away—the prisoner was brought back, and accused of taking an umbrella which we missed—she denied it—I took it from under her petticoats—this is it—Uis my master's—it was out of sight under her clothes.

CHARLES TILLIER . I am gardener to Mr. Rayner. I went after the pri
soner and took her back—she was accused of taking the umbrella—she de
nied it—it was taken from under her clothes.
(The prisoner put in a written defence, declaring her innocence.)

SAMUEL EASTMENT (police-constable V 182.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction at this Court by the name of Margaret Watson—(red
Convicted the 16th of September, 1844, having been before convicted, and an—fined six months)—the prisoner is the person.

ROBERT HICKS (police-constable P 43.) I produce a certificate of tie prisoner's conviction at Clerkenwell, by the name of Margaret Watson—(read
Convicted the 16th of september, 1844 having been befor conviced, and con
fined six months)—the prisoner is the person.
ROBERT HICKS (polic—constable p 43) I produce a certifieate of the prisoner's conviction at clerkenwell, by the name of margaret watson—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . ** Aged 18.—
confined one year

1974.
WILLIAM JACOBS,
JAMES PALMER,
WILLIAM SIMPSON , and
JOHN KING , were indicted for
stealing 10 bushels of oats, value &, the goods of
William Jones and others.

JOHN PICKARD . I am lamplighter, in the service of Mr. Monro, of Bank
side. On Saturday morning, the 29th of Aug., I left the gas—works abort ten minutes before four o'clock—I went from Pye—gardens, and was making my way towards the Stones'—end—I went under a gateway which leads from the gas—works to Bankside—it leads to White Hind
alley—the prisoner Simp
son's stable is up in the corner there—the prosecutor's place is thirty or forty yards from Simpson's stable—I observed the prisoner King there in a white smock—frock—he said, "Come on, make baste, it is all right"—there was a" tall person came out of a little alley called Cann's-alley, which is between the prosecutor's place and Simpson's stable, with a sack on his back, full of something, and he made away for Simpson's stable—I could hear the voice of two or three persons in the stable—King and the tall man, who had the sack on his back, both came from Cann's-alley, and they both went into Simpson's stable—the tall man came out again empty—handed and went into Cann's-alley again—King and the tall man passed me, but I could not see the
face of the tall man—he had the sack over his face, and was stooping as he went—I knew King—I had seen him two or three times before—Harrison, a watchman, came up, and I told him.

THOMAS HARRISON . I am private watchman to Messrs. Petty and Hanson, coal—merchants, Bankside. I know the stables of Messrs. Jones and Co.—they have a back door opening to Moss's-alley—it is almost oppo
site to Cann's-alley, which leads into White Hind
alley—Simpson's stable is at the corner of White Hind
alley, and has a door opening to Pye—gardens—I was on duty on the morning of the 29th of Aug., and Pickard called my attention to Simpson's stable door—it was open—I passed the door, and heard some persons in the stable, but I did not see them—there was a light in the stable—I saw one sack taken into that stable by a short man, who looked more like a coal—porter than anything else—I then met a couple of police
men, and told them what was transpiring.

JAMBS WELSH . I live opposite Simpson's stable; it is in a narrow pas
sage one way; the other way is wider. On the 29th of Aug. I was up at a quarter to four o'clock—I looked out at the window, and after a little while I saw the stable door open, and a man brought a sack—he stooped as he brought it—I could not tell the man—he carried it into Simpson's stable, and put H down, then brought another sack from White Hind
alley—he pitched that down in the stable, then went back and brought another—he did the same thing with that—the sacks appeared to be full—I then went to another window, where I had a view into Cann's-alley—I saw King—he was in the stable—I saw Simpson about a minute after the first sack was delivered, and before the second was delivered—he was at the door of the loft of the stable—he could see what was going on—he could see both ways—he was not doing anything—he remained there during the time I saw the other two sacks pitched—I do not know whether he remained there after that—I did not take any more account of him—I saw him distinctly—I have no doubt of his being the person—he was able to see what was going on—he could see each way—by taming over the loft door he could see into Cann's-alley—he looked out two or three times after the sacks were come—there is a gas—lamp at the corner, which was alight at the time—after the first sack had been delivered I saw. Simpson come from Pye—gardens, and go into the stable, and afterwards I saw him looking out of the door of the loft.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Where is this Pye—gardens? A. Adjoining the gas—works—Simpson came down Pye—gardens, to go to the stable—that was after the first sack had been delivered there—he was not at the stable when the first sack was delivered—I then saw him go into the stable, and go on—it was after the other two sacks had been delivered I saw him up in the loft—the other two sacks were taken in while he was in the stable—I cannot say whether it was as much as five minutes after the last sack had been delivered before I saw him up in the loft—I saw the sacks brought out of White Hind
alley into the stable.

WILLIAM ROSS (police-constable M 86.) On Saturday morning, the 29th of Aug., I was on duty in Bankside—I know Simpson's stable—I was near there about half—past three o'clock—I saw King looking out at the loft—he asked me what it was o'clock—I pulled out my watch, and said it was half—past three—I passed the stable again a little after four—I then received information—I went through Pye—gardens towards White Hind
alley—I met Bradford—we both stood by the corner of Taylor's—yard—I saw Simpson come to the door of his own stable, and look out—he came to White Hind
alley, and went to Cann's-alley—he could not see where I was standing—I went to the other end of Taylor's—yard, and saw him come to moss's-alley—I

then went to the skin—market, in Cardinal Cap
alley, and stood nt the top of the alley—I saw Simpson come out of moss's-alley, and go towards his own stable—I saw jacobs and palmer come out of the prosecutor's premises, and go toeard the Waterman's Arms public—house—they went into the public. house, and staid a minute or two—I saw them come out, and Simpson came from the corner of Pye—gardens and the public—house—I cannot say whether he came out of the public—house, but Jacobs and Palmer did—they juts ext. changed a few words, and then parted—Jacobs and Palmer returned to the prosecutor's premises—Palmer went down the yard, and Jacobs remained at the entrance, at the top—I then saw Simpson coming from towards hit own stable with a kind of bulk under his fustian coat—as he drew nearer to me I saw him deliver some sacks to Jacobs, but I cannot say how many—Simpson then ran towards his own stable—I went into the prosecutor's premises, and before Jacobs could put the sacks out of his hand, which he was going to put on a barrow, I said, "I want these sacks"—I saw Palmer, and as he me he was going into one of the prosecutor's stables—when I said to Jacobs, "I want these sacks," he said, "What do you want with them?"—I said "I want them; I have been watching your proceedings this morning"—he said, "I am very sorry for what I have done; it is the first offence; I hope you will not acquaint my master of it"—I said, "What am I placed in the street for, but to do my duty towards the public? I must do justice; I must call Mr. Kennard, the clerk"—I called him up, and made some communication to him—Mr. Sells was called—before he was called Jacobs told Mr. Kennard be was very sorry for what he had done; it was the first offence—when Mr. Sells came, we went into Simpson's stable—we there found a large bin, full of corn—we did not find any sacks of corn in the stable—I took a sample of the corn in the bit—we went back to the prosecutor's—Jacobs then said, before Mr. Kennard the others, that he was very sorry, and that they were not sacks; they weretkee cotchells—there were a few oats in the sacks when they were returned—I produce a sample of oats from Simpson's stable, and from the prosecutor's.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Where were you standing when you first saw Jacobs? A. At the top—end of Cardinal Cap
alley, towards the bank—there was nothing to prevent my seeing Jacobs and Palmer coming off the prosecutor's premises—the public—house is at the corner of Pye—gardent—these alleys have thoroughfares in all directions—I stood in that spot about five minutes—I did not change my position till I went to Jacobs for the sacks,

COUBT. Q. When you saw the bin what quantity of corn was in it? A. About six bushels—they appeared the same quality of oats, not mixed—at all—I took a sample from them, and compared it with what was at the process tor's—I saw some oats at Simpson's mixed with chaff——they seemed to be the same oats as those in the bin—I should say the whole quantity of oats would be about three sacks—Simpson is a contractor to draw coals—he has seven or eight horses.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. How much oats and chaff was on the floor? A. should say five or six sacks—there was no chaff with that in the bin.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Had Simpson a job at Richmond? A. Not at that time, he had had before—I am not aware that he sent oats to Richmond—I know where the stable is—you can get out of the proseeu
tor's stable in Moss's-alley without coming to Bankside—to get to Sinpson's you must go from Cann's-alley to White Hind
alley, and then turn to the right—the entrance to Simpson's stable looks into Pye—garden, not in" Moss's-alley—there are some houses between Simpson's stable and alley.

EDWARD PERRONET SELLS, JUN . I am carrying on business with my father and Mr. William Jones, at Bankside, in the parish of St. Saviour, Southwark. We have a stable at White Lion-wharf—we keep fourteen or fifteen horses—Jacobs was horse
keeper in our service, and resided on the premises—I know Simpson by sight, and I know his stable—the distance between that and the back door of our stable is thirty yards—it was measured by me and my partner—that back door is to allow the horses to escape in case of fire—it ought never to be opened on any other occasion—it was flat intended for any purpose of business—on the 29th of Aug. my attention was called to Jacobs being in custody—I saw him in the yard—in the presence of the policeman, and asked how he came in that position—he said he was very sorry indeed, it was the first time he had ever done anything of the kind; he hoped I would not lock him up; he would be sure to remain on the premises till he was required—I told him he was in custody of the police—I went to Simpson's premises, and found a bin with six or seven bushels of corn in it—three sacks, if full, would contain twelve bushels—I compared the corn in the Ma with that on our premises—it was exactly the same in ray opinion—there was chaff and corn lying on the floor besides the corn in the bin—! noticed the oats that were mixed with the chaff—I think they were part of the lame parcel—I heard that there had been some marks of oats seen outside my stable—I looked in the course of the day, and saw a few oats—I did not trace them.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. You have a great many men? A. We have many—we have lent sacks to persons we know—our men are not allowed to lend sacks off the premises—I do not know whether these are a common quality of oats—it is the first time we had such, to my recollection—it is not uncommon to borrow sacks—if we wanted them we should borrow them ourselves.

COURT. Q. Are these oats that are black in these samples damaged oats? A. No, I do not know that they are—I find the same proportion of shaded oati in both samples—they appear precisely the same—I cannot tea the least difference.

ROBERT BUNSFORD (police-constable M 101.) I was with Ross during part of that morning—I took Simpson—I told him what he was taken for—he said he had just heard of it in going along Bankside—he said he borrowed the sacks of Jacobs for the purpose of carrying pollard and oats to Richmond, where he had a large job, and the oats he bought of Mr. Meek, yesterday—lie said he was in the habit of buying oats of him almost every day.

JOHN MEEK . I am a corn—chandler, and live in Holland—street, Blackfiriars—road. Simpson deals with me—my attention has been called to Saturday morning, the 29th of Aug—I sold Simpson bran and beans on the Friday evening—I had not sold him any corn myself—I had not been at home in the daytime—I have ascertained that corn bad been sold to him almost everyday in the week, a sack or two—I am not able to say whether I sold him such corn as this—I had about twenty quarters of such oats as these in my possession, with some black oats mixed with them.

COURT. Q. Had you any such corn as this? A. I think these are Dutch oats—I had about twenty quarters—I think there are more black oats in these than in the Dutch oats I had—I think these are not my Dutch oats, but I had Polish oats—these are not my Polish oats.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Do you mean these are not oats you might have sold him? A. I cannot say—I have sometimes forty quarters a week, and sometimes do not untie a sack to see what they are.
COURT. Q. But you buy by sample? A. Yes, and that is very often improved—I did not buy such as these by sample.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Look at this other sample, are not these our Dutch oats? A. These are Dutch oats, and the others look a great deal like them—I can see now that these are brighter, but they are a good deal alike—they are not the same.

THOMAS KENNARD . I am clerk to the prosecutors. I have seen these three sacks, two of them are marked with our foreman's name—the other is not—I am sure these two are ours, and the other I have little doubt of—Palmer was our second horse
keeper, and slept on the premises—King was horse
keeper to Simpson.
(Witnessfor the Defence.)

RICHARD PAYNE . I am a labouring man. In the beginning of Ang. I was in Simpson's service—I remember his having a job at Richmond—I had to go about it—to cart 160 tons of coals—we ran short of sacks—he borrowed four corn—sacks of Jacobs, because he had not enough—we executed the order—we went there on the 5th of Aug., and came home on the Sunday afterwards, and went back on Monday to finish—I had the misfortune to lose one of the four sacks—when the job was finished I tied up the three sacks, and deposited them in Mr. Simpson's loft—I did not go to them till the Friday previous to Mr. Simpson being taken on the Saturday morning—I had I smock—frock with them—I had torn it, and wanted to take it home to my wife, and I went to the sacks on the Friday, and untied them to get the garter off, that I had tied them with—that was on the day before Mr. Simpson was taken—I found the sacks just as I had left them—one of the sacks had a hole in it—these sacks are a great deal like them—they are similar—they were old sacks, had been used some time, and looked to be half—worn out—they were such as these—I should not like to swear to them.

MR. BALDWIN. Q. Was it on—the Monday you put these sacks into Simpson's loft? A. Yes, on the 9th, when we came home—Mr. Simpson went to borrow the sacks—I was standing, looking at him—I saw him borrow them—I saw them lent to him—I was waiting twenty or thirty yards off—he brought four sacks to me—we borrowed four corn—sacks to take food for our horses—Mr. Simpson had some sacks—we took thirteen altogether—I got the smock—frock out from the sacks on the Friday.
COURT. Q. Do you know King? A. 1 know him by working for Mr. Simpson—he was in his stable, looking after his horses—I saw Simpson cleaning horses the last time I saw him.
(Simpson received a good character.)

JACOBS—
GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined Six Months.

PALMER—
GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

SIMPSON—
GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

KING—
GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1975.
THOMAS WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing 1 flute, 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Edward Lawrence; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

EDWARD DWYER . I am in the employ of Mr. James Edward Lawrence, of New Cut, Lambeth. On the 29th of Aug. I was in his shop, and noticed the prisoner leaning over the goods—I watched him—I went to the door, and he went away—I followed him—he crossed the road—I had suspicion, and stopped him—I found this flute in his pocket—it is my master's.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. This flute was exposed? A. Yes—there is no window to the shop—the goods are exposed for sale.

BENJAMIN BLABER (police-sergeant P 14) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at Newington Session—(read Convicted the 4th of July, 1842, and transported for seven years)—— the prisoner in the person—he had been convicted twice before.

GUILTY .—
Confined Nine Months ,

1976.
MARY ANN BRYANT and
CLARA ALDERSON were indicted for
stealing 2 shifts, value 6s.; 3 scarfs, 10s.; 1 pair of bracelets, 3s.; and 1 smelling-bottle, 1s.; the goods of
Sophia Yates: to which

BRYANT pleaded
GUILTY .—Recommended to mercy.—
Judgment Respited.

SOPHIA YATES . I am single, and live in Bartlett—street, Lambeth. Some months ago I left a box containing wearing-apparel and other things, at my uncle Bryant's, the prisoner's father—I went into the country for four months—on my return I missed from my box two shifts and some other things—the two prisoners slept together when I was in the house, and I left my box in the room they used—I did not charge Alderson with breaking my box open, but with pawning the things—I learnt from her that I might expect to find them at Mr. Matthews', the pawnbroker—three scarfs, a smelling-bottle, and a great many little things are still missing—the things that are here are mine—I know this night—gown by the mark, and I know these others by the make of them—I found them in consequence of what Alderson told me.

WILLIAM BRYANT . I am the prisoner Bryant's father—I live at Lambeth—myniece, Sophia Yates, left a box with me—my daughter and Alderson slept in the room where the box was—about the 10th of Aug. my daughter left the house, and I found my niece's box had been broken open—my daughter was brought home, and I accused her and Alderson with breaking the box open—my daughter acknowledged to breaking it open—Alderson acknowledged to pawning the things, but denied breaking the box—I found some duplicates—I redeemed all the things that I knew of, but the things that are here I was not aware of.

HANNAH MALLETT . My husband is a tailor—we live in Fair-street, Lambeth—Alderson came to tea with me one evening in August—she left a black handkerchief on my table, and a smelling-bottle in a china case—I returned them to her on the Tuesday morning afterwards.

SOPHIA YATES
re-examined. That was the description of smelling—bottle I lost

MARIA TOTTELL . I am the wife of Richard Tottell, and live at Lambeth. I was passing Alderson's lodging one day—she beckoned me, and brought a black handkerchief and a smelling—bottle to the door—I said, "I won't take them."

CHARLES WILLIAMS . I am in the employ of Mr. Matthews, a pawn
broker. These two shifts and a bed—gown were pawned by Alderson.

EDWARD DIXON (police-constable L 85.) I took Alderson into custody—I told her it was for a robbery at Mr. Bryant's—she said, "Is it not settled yet? he gave me in charge once"—I said, "No, there are more things miss
ing"—she said, "I know nothing about it."

Aldcrson's Defence, I went out one day, and when I returned a lodger in the house told me that Mary Ann had broken open her cousin's box; I went up stairs and found it was so; I asked the reason she had done so, and scolded her; she made up a bundle the next morning, and asked me to take 't to pawn; I hesitated some time; I then took it; I brought her back the money and the duplicates; I had not the least idea I was doing wrong.

ALDERSON—
NOT GUILTY .

1977.
HUGH SOMERS was indicted
for stealing 1 bundle of cigars, value 24s.; the goods of
Theophilus Clark; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

1978.
JOHN ELSWORTHY and
WILLIAM HAYNES were indicted for
stealing 32lbs. weight of beef, value 18s.; the goods of
Henry Caswell.

RICHARD CASWELL . I am in the service of my brother, Henry Caswell, a butcher, in Belvidere—place, Southwark. On Saturday afternoon last I was outside the shop, about three o'clock, and saw the prisoners standing at the end of the window-board—there was a rump of beef on the end of the board—I was called to attend in the shop, and when I came back the beef was gone—it was about 32lbs. weight—it was worth about 18s.—we sell it at 7 1/2 d. a lb.—I gave information, and afterwards saw the prisoners in custody.
Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. Were there many persons about the shop? A. Not a great many, ten or a dozen perhaps.

SARAH JANE HARRISON . I am the wife of James Harrison—I live in Flint—street, Southwark. On Saturday, the 19th of Sept., I was in King, street—I saw the prisoners come from Friar-street into King-street, in a direction from the prosecutor's shop—as they passed I saw Elsworthy bid a large rump of beef under his left arm—I was speaking to a friend—it was covered with a dirty handkerchief, but the tail of the beef hung out—I went on and was passing the prosecutor's shop—Richard Caswell said to me,"I have lost a rump of beef"—I told him what I had seen, and gave information to the police—the prisoners appeared to be in company—Haynes was walk
ing by the left side of Elsworthy—I am quite sure they are the persons.

Cross-examined. Q. King-street is rather crowded? A. No—it leads into Friar-street, and up into Union-street—I did not notice any person but the person I was speaking to—I had never seen either of the prisoners before—it was about five minutes' walk from the prosecutor's—both the prisoners had caps on, nearly alike, close caps to their heads—one of them was dressed in fustian—it was a few minutes after three o'clock.
Q. Did you not express some doubt whether Elsworthy was the person? A. When I saw him I said I was not sure, but when he stood up I was sure—I now know that he is respectably connected.

WILLIAM ALFRED HEADINGTON . I am in the service of Mr. Elwood, who keeps the Friar public-house, in Friar-street. Last Saturday I was in the back washhouse, cleaning my pots—the prisoners came in, and Elsworthy produced a dirty handkerchief with about 1 1/2lb. of rump steak in it—I noticed that it was cut some part thick and some thin—it was not equally cut—he asked if I would cook that steak for him—I said, "Yes"—I said, "Have you got some cow-beef?" seeing it was in a dirty handkerchief—he said, "No, it is good rump—steak, it cost me 10d. a pound"—they had the steak and eat it, and left the house—they seemed in very great agitation, and came to me three times while I was cooking it—it was about four o'clock—my master's is not more than two minutes walk from the prosecutor's.
Cross-examined. Q. Were the prisoners dressed in fustian? A. One of them I think had a corduroy jacket on—I did not notice their caps—I never saw a steak cut as that was.

HENRY BARRY (police-constable Mill.) I apprehended Elsworthy at his house, and took him to Mrs. Harrison—I told him I wanted him for stealing a rump of beef from Mr. Caswell, a butcher—he said he knew nothing of it—when Mrs. Harrison camein he was sitting down—she did not appear to know him—I told him to stand up, and she said, "That is him"—I
took him to the station—he said he did not know why he should be taken by himself—why not take Haynes—I sent another officer for Haynes.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you know Elsworthy has been a respectable lad up to this time? A. Yes; he is the son of respectable parents, who have lived in the neighbourhood twenty years—his father held a situation in the Queen's Bench prison.

HENRY HUNT (police-constable M 82.) I went to Lant-place, and apprehended Haynes—I told him I took him on a charge of being concerned with Elsworthy in stealing a piece of beef from Mr. Caswell's shop—he said, "I know nothing about it, and know no person of the name of Elsworthy."

ELSWORTHY—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

HAYNES *—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

1979.
CHARLES EAST was indicted
for feloniously receiving 2 bushels of oats and beans, value 6s.; the goods of
William Moon, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute. (See page 819, No, 1962.)

WILLIAM MOON . I am a carrier, and live at Godalmin. On the 6th of Sept. I had a person named Edwards in my service as a wagoner—I had missed several lots of corn, and been robbed to a great extent—on Sunday, the 6th of Sept, I went in my hay—loft and found some corn, which had no business there—I examined it—it was mine—the same description as what I had—there was about two bushels—it consisted of white oats, black oats, and split beans—I did not see any chicken's grits with it—I had before then been in communication with the officer, and he had full access to my stable—I gave information to the officer—next morning, about eleven o'clock, I gave out to Edwards, five bushels of corn in two sacks, and one sack of chaff to come to town—he had a right to take those three sacks—I made out his bill, but did not look into the wagon to see what he hadgot,

WILLIAM HENRY BIDDLECOMB . I am chief constable of Godalmin. On Sunday, the 6th of Sept., I went to Mr. Moon's stable—the corn and bay loft are on the same floor, over the stable—you pass through the hay loft to get to the corn loft—I looked under some hay lying in the loft, and saw a sack with about two bushels of corn in it, consisting of white oats, black oats, and split beans—I mixed about a pint of chicken's grits with it, and after I had so mixed it, I took a sample of it, which I have here—another sample has been shown to me since by Goff—I have compared the sample I have with the sample I saw—I have no doubt it is the same I mixed the grits with—I marked the sack with grey worsted—I have seen it since produced by Goff—it was the sack in which the corn was that I mixed the grits with—I took the prisoner in charge at Newington Sessions-house—I asked him what account he could give of those oats he had in his stable, that he had from Edwards—he said he knew nothing about it, he never had Any from Edwards.

WILLIAM WIGGINS . It was my duty to attend Mr. Moon's wagon I left Godalmin on Monday, the 7th of Sept., and arrived in London on Tuesday morning—Edwards put three sacks of corn into the wagon and one of chaff—my attention had been directed to a marked sack—when we arrived at the Queen's Head in the Borough only one of the sacks was put into Mr. Moon's stable—I never took notice whether that was the marked sack—one sack was found in the ostler's stable, which is about forty yards from Mr. Moon's stable—the prisoner attends the ostler's stable—my master's corn had no business in the ostler's stable—I saw it there about seven o'clock—I had seen in the wagon several times—I did not see the contents of the

sack—I looked in the sack in the stable and Mr. Steel took a sample out—I told the book
keeper (Mr. Steel) I should say it was my master's corn—it was standing by the ostler's bin.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. You have the charge of the wagon, and Edwards of the horses? A. Yes—the four sacks were in the wagon when we brought it up.

COURT. Q. What was the con and chaff brought to London for? A. For the horses to eat—it was partly used on the road, and the rest should be put into Mr. Moon's stable—one sack was put in his stable—my attention had been called to a marked sack before we started—I knew the sack—I saw the sacks of corn in the wagon, but I did not see them taken away—I unloaded the wagon, the other man took care of the horses.

JOHN STEEL . I am book
keeper at the Queen's Head Inn in the Borough—the prisoner is ostler there—we have a stable called the Nag's stable—the prisoner had the control of it—Wiggins called my attention to a sack there, on Tuesday, the 8th of Sept.—it was standing by the corn-bin—a man named Moore was there—I took a sample of corn from the sack and gave it to Goff.

COURT. Q. How was the prisoner employed? A. By Mr. Walker, my employer—my master has no horses—we call it the ostler's stable because he has his corn-bin there, and gentlemen's horses come there—they pay the ostler, and he is to account to me every night—he could not make a profit of any corn in that stable without he sold it to other carriers in the stable—it would be of no use to him—he charges for baits—I saw Edwards and the prisoner together in that stable, that day, three or four hours afterwards—the sack was still there.
Cross-examined. Q. It would be the prisoner's duty to be in that stable? A. Yes, but not always—about six horses could stand there—no one else came in there to my knowledge.

JEREMIAH MOORE . I am a labourer, I was in the stable at the Queen's Head on Tuesday, the 8th of Sept.—I had come from Epsom that morning, I arrived about six o'clock, but my horse in the prisoner's stable—I went into the stable to go sleep, I laid down on the corn-bin—I beleive that is the bin he serves his corn from—I have not seen him go been there some time, I saw the prisoner bring in a sack on his shoulder—he put it down by the side of the corn-bin—he went out—Mr. Steel came in afterwards, and went to the same sack as the prisoner brought in.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had you slept? A. I do not know—when the prisoner came in with the corn he awoke me—I remained awake till Mr. Steel came in—I had had a hard day's work before—I had one horse and a van—I brought up corn with me—I carried it into the Queens Head stable, which is the ordinary course—the door of the stable was open, anybody may come in and out—it is common for people to lie down there, and go to sleep.
MR. CHARNOCK. Q. I suppose you do not take your master's corn into Mr. Moon's stables? A. No, into our own stables.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant L 8.) On Friday, the 11th of Sept., I found this sack in front of Mr. Moon's wagon, going back to Godalmin—I have a sample of oats and beans which were given me by Mr. Steel.

WILLIAM BIDDLBCOMB
re-examined. This is the sack I marked on the 6th of Sept.—here is the same mixture of grits in this corn that I mixed on the Sunday, and it is the same description of corn—there is no doubt it is the same—it is black oats, white oats, and split-beans.

JOHN STEEL
re-examined. I cannot swear to the sack—it is like the I saw in the stable.

COURT to WILLIAM WIGGINS. Q. Did you see any sacks put in or taken out of the wagon? A. No—there were three sacks of corn in and one sack of chaff—I did not see Edwards load them, but he did load them most likely——they were in the wagon when it got to London.

WILLIAM MOON
re-examined. In consequence of losing corn, I put a second lock on my granary—there were three lots of corn in my granary on Monday morning, and as soon as the wagon was gone the corn was gone—Edwards had keys to go to my granary when he liked.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant,

1980.
JOHN ROBINSON and
CHARLES WATSON were indicted for
stealing 2 1/2lbs. weight of beef, value 1s. 3d., the goods of
Daniel Harling; to which

ROBINSON pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Three Months ,

HENRY WHITTAL . I was at Clapham on the 23rd of Sept., and saw the prisoners together—they then separated, and Robinson went to the butcher's shop, and took a piece of beef—he put it into his sack—he then looked round, and took another piece—Watson was at some distance, looking in at a win
dow—they then joined, and Robinson gave one piece of beef out of his bag to Watson.
Watson. I gave this prisoner 1s. to go and buy some meat; he brought me one piece, and said it cost 10 1/2 d.; I could not tell whether he bought it or not.
EDWIN COLLINS . I am servant to Daniel Harling. I was in the stable—I came out, and missed the beef—it was produced, and the prisoners were taken—it was my master's.
ROBERT EMERSON ( police-sergeant V—9.) I took the prisoners—there were two half-crowns, a sixpence, and 6d. worth of halfpence found on Robinson, but no shilling.

WATSON *—
GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined Nine Months ,

1981.
GEORGE GILES and
TIMOTHY SULLIVAN were indicted for
stealing 2 bottles, value 2d.; 1 quart of stout, 10d.; and 6 cheroots, 1s.; the goods of
William Benjamin Powell.

MARY ANN POWELL . I am the wife of William Benjamin Powell—we keep a beer-shop at Battersea. The prisoners came there on the 21st of Sept., about one o'clock—they had some dinner and some porter—after they left I missed some cheroots out of a glass—I suspected the prisoners, as no one else had been in the bouse—in a little time my husband came in and asked if I had sold some stout—I said, "No"—he said the prisoners were drinking some stout in the lane—I missed some stout, but I cannot say what—two bottles were brought back—they are mine.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q., Who paid for what they had at your house? A. Sullivan—the stout was kept in the bar, and the cheroots were further in the bar, near the parlour—door—they are worth 2d. a-piece.,

WILLIAM BENJAMIN POWELL . I keep the beer-shop. I gave information to the policeman, and he took the prisoners—he took the cheroots from Giles—one bottle of the stout was between the prisoners as they were lying in the road in Falcon-lane—I have examined the cheroots and these bottles of stout—they are mine to the best of my belief—the prisoners were a little the worse for liquor.
JOHN SMITH . I am a glover, and live in High-street, Battersea. On the
21st of Sept. I saw the prisoners sitting in the road, and scraping the labels off the stout—bottles.
Cross-examined. Q. Which was doing that? A. I cannot say which—I did not see their features—they were men similar to the prisoners.
WILLIAM HARRINGTON . I saw Giles take a bottle out of his pocket and throw it over awall—I went after it—it did not break—it contained liquor, I do not know what—I gave it to Mr. Powell.

GILES—
GUILTY . Aged 43.

SULLIVAN—
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Confined Ten days .

1982.
WILLIAM JONES was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 15s., the goods of
Henry John Wharton, and another.
HENRY STACEY . I am in the service of Henry John Wharton, and another, pawnbrokers, at Newington—causeway. I missed a coat on the evening of the 14th of Sept.—I have not seen it

JAMES KEARLEY (police-sergeant P 36.) I saw the prisoner steal the coat, on Monday night, the 14th of Sept., at a quarter before nine o'clock—I had watched him for a quarter of an hour before—I was in plain clothes—I was looking at him very minutely—I could not take him on account of so many persons being in the road—it was the Surrey Zoological Gardens night, and I could not get across—I know it was him—I had watched him three nights—he had some difficulty in getting the coat off the blind—he took it with two hands.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. You were watching? A. Yes—he had another with him—there were very few persons between me and the shop; but I could not take the prisoner, it was done so quick—an omnibus stopped opposite a dark turning, and I was on the opposite side—I just turned into the road, and there I missed him, the crowd was so great—there was not a crowd at the shop—I did not cry "Stop thief!"
NOT GUILTY .

1983.
CATHERINE CONNER was indicted
for stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; 5 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence; the property of
Edward Walter, from his person; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

EDWARD WALTER . I am a corporal in the Royal Artillery, at Woolwich. On the 22nd of Sept., between eight and nine o'clock at night, I met the prisoner on London-bridge—she induced me to turn down a dark court with her, on the left—hand side off the bridge—in two or three minutes a man stepped in front of us, and both he and the prisoner ran away—a watchman came up, and asked if I had lost anything, and my purse was gone—it had 5l. 12s. 6d. in it—I had had it about two minutes before, when I crossed the bridge—it was in my right-hand trowsers pocket—I did not feel anything at my pocket—I identified it when it was in the possession of the inspector—the money was init when I saw it again.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. I suppose you would not have gone with her if you had not been drinking? A. I had been drinking a glass of half-and-half—I am married—I should not have gone with her if it had not been for her persuasion—I went down by a dead wall—it was by the side of the railway station, going to Woolwich—it was rather dark there—nothing took place between us—I had not my hand on her—she had her hand on me—I did not give her anything—she did not wait for that—she did

ask me for money, I swear that—after I had been with her some time a man came—I cannot positively assert what the man said—it was something to the effect, "I have caught you"—that was directed to both of us, I presume—the prisoner ran away directly she saw him step in front—I was standing up—I never had to make a similar charge—this is my purse—I have had it some time—there was no word mentioned about what I was to give her——I did not intend to give her anything.

JOSEPH WILLY . I am a private watchman of Montague-close—a little be
fore nine o'clock that night I saw the prisoner walking with the prosecutor arm in arm, and a man walking twenty yards behind them—they went down a passage, and the other man went and leaned his arm against the boards, where he could peep round the corner—I went to look at that man's face, bat he turned from me—I then went back and told the policeman—I then heard a cough given as a signal, and the man who was standing round the corner went to the prosecutor—the prisoner ran away directly, and the policeman caught her—I then saw her throw the purse down, about three yards behind the policeman—I saw him pick it up.

Cross-examined. Q. Where were you? A. I was under the arch first, then I walked down, and saw them go down this dark place together—not half a minute elapsed before the man followed them—he came and leaned against the boards.

THOMAS O'SHAUGHNESSY (police-eenstable M 146.) About nine o'clock that evening I saw the prisoner and the prosecutor together in Montague
place—Willy spoke to me, and called my attention to them—I told him to watch them, while I concealed myself behind a cart—I remained some time, and saw the prisoner approach me, running—she did not see me—I stopped her immediately—I heard something fall on the ground, I stooped for it she got away, but I followed and picked up this purse—when I stooped for it she got away, but I followed and took her again—she entreated me to let her go, and laid she would recompense me on another occasion—for the sake of her poor mother and her child she entreated me to let her go.

Cross-examined. Q. Did she not say, "For God's sake let me go, I did not know I had the purse?" A. Yes, she said a great deal—it was some time before the prosecutor came up—I called him, and another man came up—he was not the prisoner's husband—her husband died last summer——it was a man that is living with her.

WILLIAM LEWIS (City police-constable, No. 566.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted 11th May, 1846, and confined six weeks)—the prisoner is the person—I had her in custody four years ago for a felony in Monument-yard.

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

1984.
JAMES ABBEY was indicted
for unlawfully assaulting
Louisa Powell, aged 13, with intent, &c.; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Nine Months.

div0.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, THE 26TH OF OCTOBER.
